Award.AwardTitle: Asymptotic and Spectral Analysis of Applied Non-self-adjoint Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is the development of mathematical tools for studying several problems emerging from physics and modern mathematical biology. The first two problems concern propagation of waves in non-homogeneous media and optical fibers. The results can be used for detection of hidden objects, nondestructive testing and estimation of the quality of signal transmission in the noisy environment. Further, a mathematical model will be developed for molecular motors used by biophysicists to describe processes in living cells. The model will justify certain hypotheses in the area and will describe quantitatively the parameters for which the hypotheses hold. The last problem concerns the mathematical analysis of modern models of population dynamics aiming to explain the mechanism for non-local and fast propagation of new species. The existence of stable populations with competition between species will be also explained.

On a more technical level, the project includes problems in homogenization, spectral theory of non-standard Hamiltonians, and singularly perturbed partial differential equations needed to address the applied problems mentioned above. In particular, the following results will be obtained. The Weyl law for the counting function of eigenvalues of (non-self-adjoint) interior transmission problem will be established. Localization theorem will be proved for waveguides with randomly perturbed surfaces. The homogenization principle will be justified for molecular motors. Front propagation will be studied for general contact processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The results obtained include the following.

1) The concept of a Brownian (molecular) motor has fundamental applications in the study of transport processes in living cells and (in a slightly different form) in the porous media theory. There are thousands of publications (not mathematically rigorous) in the area of Brownian motors in physics and biology journals. A rigorous mathematical theory of Brownian motors was developed. Homogenization theorems were proved, and explicit formulas were found for the effective drift and effective diffusivity.

2) A mathematical analysis was given for the protein phase transition in living cells from the globular (folded) to the diffusive (unfolded) form. An explanation was given for the decay of the diffusivity near the critical value of the temperature where the transition from folded to the unfolded form occurs. This decay is an experimental fact in the physics of proteins that contradicts the earlier theory.

3) Population dynamics studies questions that come up in mathematical biology, demographics, and sociology. The central problems in population dynamics concern conditions for the existence of steady states (statistical equilibriums) and conditions for the stability of a steady state with respect to small perturbations of the environment. These problems were studied in both continuous and discrete models. In particular, the front propagation of a population was described, conditions for the stability of the population were studied, and intermittency was investigated. The latter is a characteristic of non-uniformity of the population. A mechanism for non-local and fast propagation of new species was explained. The study of continuous models was based on new results concerning spectral properties of convolution operators and their perturbations. The discrete models used new results on branching processes with heavy tails.

4) An effective procedure was suggested for solving inverse problems (arising in non-destructive testing, medical and other applications)  with reduced data, i.e., when the source of the incident waves is located on a smooth closed surface outside of the obstacle or inhomogeneity of the media and the scattered waves are measured on the same surface. This allows one to apply inverse problems when an observer has access to the support of the obstacle/inhomogeneity only from one side.

5) The inside-outside duality principle in scattering by inhomogeneous media was justified. Direct relation between the spectral flow of interior transmission eigenvalues and the direction of rotation of the eigenvalues of the scattering matrix was discovered.

6) The quasi-classical spectral asymptotics were found and justified for the Schrodinger operators on unbounded fractals. The results can be applied in biological and medical problems.  Examples of the Schrodinger operators on fractals were constructed for which the exponential localization takes place, but the spectrum is non-Poissonian. These examples disprove an old physical conjecture.

7) A Weyl-type formula for the counting function of interior transmission eigenvalues was found and justified.
